title: Automatic Selection of Context Configurations for Improved Class-Specific Word Representations
abstract: Recent work has demonstrated that state-of-the-art word embedding models require different context types to produce high-quality representations for different word classes such as adjectives (A), verbs (V), and nouns (N). This paper is concerned with identifying contexts useful for learning A/V/N-specific representations. We introduce a simple yet effective framework for selecting class-specific context configurations that yield improved representations for each class. We propose an automatic A* style selection algorithm that effectively searches only a fraction of the large configuration space. The results on predicting similarity scores for the A, V, and N subsets of the benchmarking SimLex-999 evaluation set indicate that our method is useful for each class: the improvements are 6% (A), 6% (V), and 5% (N) over the best previously proposed context type for each class. At the same time, the model trains on only 14% (A), 26.2% (V), and 33.6% (N) of all dependency-based contexts, resulting in much shorter training time.
